talk.start.para: r asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

item.para: How many government-owned houses were there inCanberra at the 31st December in each of the following years: 1939, 1940, 1941, 1942, 1943, and 1944?
How many such houses were occupiedby (a.) Commonwealth public servants, and (b) private citizens at the 31st December in each of those years?
How many houses have been built in Canberra by the Government in each year since 1939?

How many (a) public servants and (b) private individuals have applied for houses in Canberra in each year since 1939 and in each month since the beginning of this year, and how many homes have been provided for each class of applicant in each of the periods mentioned?
How many (a) public servants and (b) private individuals are now waiting for houses in Canberra?

Is it a fact that the policy of the department is to ignore the claims of private individuals whose employment makes it essential that they should live in Canberra, and. in the allocation of houses, to reserve homes exclusively for public servants?

In view of the fact that war-time restrictions make it impossible for private enterprise to erecthouses in Canberra, will the Government take action to ensure that housing appli cants who are not public servants, especially those with two or more children, are given opportunities to obtain a home similar to those given members of the Public Service.
What immediate action does the Government intend to take to relieve the housing shortage in Canberra?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for the Interior has supplied the following answers : -

item.para: * The reduction is due to houses havingbeen sold to tenants.
It is not possible to give this information.

It is not possible to give this information. The number of government-owned houses occupied by (a) public servants and government employees and (b) private individuals at the present time is 1,709 and 340, respectively.
(a) Public servants and other government employees, 365; and (b) private individuals, 165.
No. Preference is, however, given to public servants and persons engaged on essential government undertakings.

Houses have been erected : by the De partment of the Interior primarily for housing public servants and government employees. Until the housing position improves, it will be difficult to allot houses to other applicants. Permits to erect houses are, however, being issued by the Department of War Organization of Industry to applicants on the basis of need.
Contracts have been let by the Department of the Interior for the erection of 90 houses and other contracts will be arranged within the limited resources of material and man-power available.

talk.start.para: n asked the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: With reference to the question asked by the honorable member for Bendigo on the 8th March, regarding allegations that Italians and others, released from internment camps, had been permitted to return to their homes, farms and businesses in military areas while Australians who entered those areas were liable to arrest and severe penalty, will he inform the House of the result of the examination he promised to have made?
If the allegations have been found to be correct, what action does he propose to take to preserve the security of Australia?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: As explained by the Attorney-General in reply to the honorable member's question on Sth March, certain Italian exinternees have been released for work in north Queensland. In all such cases, the Director-General of Security was satisfied that the Italians concerned are no longer a security risk. With the changed situation of the war, the high priority given by the Food Production Executive to sugar workers and the acute labour shortage to meet man-power requirements a number of Italians were released from service in the Civil Aliens Corps for engagement in caue, cuttingandat the end of the season were redirected to employment in other avenues of primary production by the manpowerauthorities in north Queensland. It is assumed the second part of the question refers to the Cairns Prohibition Order. If this is so, the prohibition contained therein operates against all persons; thus both Australians and aliens are excluded from returning to the area specified in the Order except under the authority of a permit issued by the Department of the Army. So far as Security Service is concerned, noalien of any description is recommended to the Army for a permit except under circumstances of a compassionate nature, and then only if he is not a security risk.In conclusion, Icanonly repeat the assurance previously given to the honorable member by the Attorney-General, namely, that the first consideration in all these cases is the preservationof the security of Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Acting Minister for the Array, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that a message was sent by the Prime Minister to the troops in New Guinea that they could speak their minds freely to the Acting Minister for the Army on his recent visit to the northern battle areas ?
Is ita fact that when SenatorFraser arrivedatLae he was several hours late?
Is ita fact that there were approxi mately 300 soldiers waiting to speak to him?
Is it a fact that the Acting Minister stopped, said he was very late and very weary, spoke to one soldier and went on his way?
If so, is this carrying out either the letter or the spirit of the Prime Minister's message ?

talk.start.para: n. - The Acting Minister for the Army has supplied the following answers : -

item.para: Yes.

No. My time-table was regularly adhered to throughout the whole period" with the exception of my visit to Lae when, because of following winds for the journey from Atherton to Nadzab which is the airport for Lae, I arrived half an hour ahead of my schedule and, on the arrival of the general officer commanding the First Australian Army, we proceeded immediately to his head-quarters at Lae for lunchaccording to schedule.

No. During the whole period of my tour special or formal parades were not held and no formal gatherings of soldiers to meet me were arranged in advance ofmy visit to any area. I have no knowledge of there being 300 or any lesser number of soldiers waiting to speak to me at Lae, and if there had been, J would certainly have been glad to have spoken with them.

No; there is no truth whatever in this. At no time during my visits to Lae or any of the operational areas was any such reply, or any reply evenapproaching it, given by me to any soldier.I have the interests of the soldiers far too muchat heart to treat them in such a way.

At all places visited by me I carried out to the best of my ability the spirit and the letter of the Prime Minister's message. If I did not see every soldier in these areas, as the honorable member evidently thinksI should have, it was because this was physically impossible, hut I did see as many soldiers as I possibly could in every area I visited.

answer.para: It may he of interest to the honorable member to know that Laeis the head-quarters and the mainbase of theFirst Australian Army and cannot, by the greatest stretch of the imagination,be deemed to be a battle area. The northern buttle areas referred to by the honorable memberare: New Britain, 375 miles distant from Lae; Solomons, 550 miles distant from Lae; Aitape, New Guinea, 450 miles distant from Lae.

My main purpose in visiting Lae was to confer with the general officer commanding First Australian Army, and immediately after lunch on myarrival at Lae I was in conference with him for some hours. Subsequently. I visited a number of the base units including the hospital and conferred with the men. J also visited the Men's Club at the time of the evening meat and spoke to a number of men there and subsequently visited the members of the Australian Army Nursing Service.I have no apologies to make for my activities at Lae or any other area which I visited.I consider that, in comparison with men serving in actual battle areas, the men at the base at Lae are reasonably well off and should have little cause for complaint.
